sections.chief_complaint: 67-year-old male presents for pre-operative assessment prior to scheduled aortic valve replacement.
sections.history_of_present_illness: Patient reports progressive dyspnea on exertion over the past 6 months. Denies chest pain at rest. No syncope or presyncope. Able to climb one flight of stairs before becoming short of breath.
sections.cardiac_history: Moderate aortic stenosis (valve area 1.1 cmÂ²) diagnosed 2 years ago. Hypertension controlled on current regimen. No prior cardiac surgery.
sections.physical_exam: BP 132/78, HR 68, SpO2 98% on room air. Regular rate and rhythm. 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at right upper sternal border radiating to carotids.
sections.assessment_plan: Patient cleared for AVR from anesthesia standpoint. Will proceed with surgery as scheduled. Recommend continuing beta-blocker perioperatively.

source_transcript: Good morning Mr. Jackson, I'm Dr. Raubenheimer. I see you're here for your pre-op assessment for your aortic valve surgery. How are you feeling today? [Patient: Pretty good, just get a bit winded going up stairs.] How many flights can you climb? [Patient: About one, then I need to rest.] Any chest pain? [Patient: No, not really.] Any passing out or feeling like you might pass out? [Patient: No.] Good. Let me check your medications - you're on metoprolol? [Patient: Yes, 50 twice a day.] And lisinopril? [Patient: Yes, 10 in the morning.] Aspirin? [Patient: The baby aspirin, yes.] Any allergies to medications? [Patient: None that I know of.] Great. Your echo from last month shows moderate aortic stenosis with a valve area of 1.1 cm squared. We'll proceed with the AVR as planned for next Tuesday. Keep taking your metoprolol - that's important around surgery.
